description: Complete G3 question bank from Phase 1 verification and Phase 2 generation (Units 1-9)

questions.question_text: What is the definition of combustion air?

options.A: The ambient air that is admitted to a venting system at the draft hood
options.B: The air required for satisfactory combustion of gas, including excess air
options.C: Air that is admitted to a space containing an appliance to replace exhausted air
options.D: That portion of combustion air supplied in excess of theoretical requirements

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.3 - Combustion air: the air required for satisfactory combustion of gas, including excess air.
questions.explanation: Option B matches the official CSA B149.1-25 definition exactly. Option A describes flue gas dilution air (Clause 3.5), Option D describes excess air (Clause 3.4).

questions.question_text: Which category of appliance operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a flue loss not less than 17%?
questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.8 - Category I appliance: an appliance that operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a flue loss not less than 17%.
questions.explanation: Category I = nonpositive pressure + flue loss >= 17%. Category II (3.9) = nonpositive + <17%. Category III (3.10) = positive + >=17%. Category IV (3.11) = positive + <17%.

questions.question_text: What is a Category IV appliance?

options.A: An appliance that operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a flue loss not less than 17%
options.B: An appliance that operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a flue loss less than 17%
options.C: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss not less than 17%
options.D: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss less than 17%

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.11 - Category IV appliance: an appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss less than 17%.
questions.explanation: Category IV appliances are high-efficiency condensing appliances with positive vent pressure and flue loss <17%.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'excess air'?

options.A: The air required for satisfactory combustion of gas
options.B: That portion of the combustion air supplied to the combustion zone in excess of that theoretically required
options.C: The ambient air admitted to a venting system at the draft hood
options.D: Air that replaces air exhausted through a ventilation opening

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.4 - Excess air: that portion of the combustion air that is supplied to the combustion zone in excess of that which is theoretically required for complete combustion.
questions.explanation: Option B matches the official definition. Option A is combustion air (3.3), Option C is flue gas dilution air (3.5).

questions.question_text: Which type of automatic vent damper device is controlled by electrical energy?
questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.15 - Electrically operated vent damper device: an automatic vent damper device that is controlled by electrical energy.
questions.explanation: Option B is the exact definition. Thermally actuated (3.16) depends on thermal energy of vent gases converted to mechanical energy.

questions.question_text: What is a draft hood designed to do?

options.A: Only ensure ready escape of flue gases
options.B: Only prevent backdraft from entering the combustion chamber
options.C: Ensure escape of flue gases, prevent backdraft, and neutralize stack action effects
options.D: Only neutralize the effect of stack action

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.65 - Draft hood: designed to ensure the ready escape of flue gases from the combustion chamber; prevent a backdraft from entering the combustion chamber; and neutralize the effect of stack action.
questions.explanation: The draft hood has three functions as stated in Clause 3.65. Options A, B, and D each describe only one function.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of a direct-vent appliance?

options.A: An appliance where combustion products are mixed with the medium being heated
options.B: An appliance where all combustion air is supplied directly from outdoors and products vented directly outdoors
options.C: An appliance that uses room air for combustion
options.D: An appliance with a draft hood for venting

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.56 - Direct-vent appliance: an appliance constructed so that all the combustion air is supplied directly from, and the products of combustion are vented directly to, the outdoors.
questions.explanation: Option B matches the definition. Option A describes a direct-fired appliance (3.55).

questions.question_text: What is the difference between forced draft and induced draft?

options.A: Forced draft is natural, induced draft is mechanical
options.B: Forced draft is upstream from combustion zone, induced draft is downstream
options.C: Forced draft is downstream, induced draft is upstream
options.D: There is no difference between them

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.61 - Forced draft: mechanical draft produced by a device upstream from the combustion zone. Section 3.62 - Induced draft: mechanical draft produced by a device downstream from the combustion zone.
questions.explanation: Both are mechanical drafts. The key difference is location relative to combustion zone: forced = upstream, induced = downstream.

questions.question_text: What is a continuous pilot?

options.A: A pilot that is automatically lighted each time there is a call for heat
options.B: A pilot that burns without turndown whether the main burner is firing or not
options.C: A pilot that is cut off at the end of the trial-for-ignition period
options.D: A pilot that burns at low turndown and increases upon call for heat

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.137 - Continuous pilot: a pilot that burns without turndown throughout the entire time the burner is in service, whether the main burner is firing or not.
questions.explanation: Option A describes intermittent pilot (3.139). Option C describes interrupted pilot (3.140). Option D describes expanding pilot (3.138).

questions.question_text: What is an intermittent pilot?

options.A: A pilot that burns continuously without turndown
options.B: A pilot automatically lighted with each call for heat and burns while main burner fires
options.C: A pilot that is cut off at the end of the trial-for-ignition period
options.D: A pilot that increases flow upon call for heat

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.139 - Intermittent pilot: a pilot that is automatically lighted each time there is a call for heat and that burns during the entire period that the main burner is firing.
questions.explanation: Option A is continuous pilot (3.137). Option C is interrupted pilot (3.140). Option D is expanding pilot (3.138).

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'approved'?

options.C: Acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.12 - Approved: acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction.
questions.explanation: This is distinct from 'certified' (3.36) which refers to investigation by a testing organization. Approved is a broader acceptance by the AHJ.

questions.question_text: What is a barometric damper?

options.B: A draft-control device intended to stabilize natural draft by admitting room air
options.C: A device that increases draft pressure
options.D: A device that prevents flue gas escape

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.66 - Draft regulator (barometric damper): a draft-control device intended to stabilize the natural draft in an appliance by admitting room air to the venting system.
questions.explanation: The barometric damper stabilizes draft by admitting room air when draft is excessive. It does not prevent backdraft (that's a draft hood function).

questions.question_text: What is the definition of combustion products?

options.A: Only carbon dioxide and water vapor
options.B: Constituents that result from combustion including inert gases but excluding excess air
options.C: Only flue gases and carbon monoxide

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.42 - Combustion products: constituents that result from the combustion of gas with the oxygen of the air and include inert gases but exclude excess air.
questions.explanation: Key distinction: combustion products exclude excess air, while flue gases (3.93) include both combustion products AND excess air.

questions.question_text: What is a fan-assisted burner?

options.A: A burner with combustion air supplied by mechanical device at pressure to overcome burner resistance only
options.B: A burner with combustion air supplied to overcome burner and appliance resistance
options.C: A burner not equipped with mechanical device for supplying combustion air
options.D: A burner that uses natural draft only

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.33 - Fan-assisted burner: a burner in which the combustion air is supplied by a mechanical device such as a fan or blower at sufficient pressure to overcome the resistance of the burner only.
questions.explanation: Option B describes forced-draft burner (3.34) which overcomes resistance of both burner AND appliance. Option C describes natural-draft burner (3.35).

questions.question_text: What is a forced-draft burner?

options.A: A burner with air supplied to overcome burner resistance only
options.B: A burner with air supplied at sufficient pressure to overcome resistance of both burner and appliance
options.C: A burner not equipped with mechanical device
options.D: A burner that relies on natural draft

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.34 - Forced-draft burner: a burner in which the combustion air is supplied by a mechanical device such as a fan or blower at sufficient pressure to overcome the resistance of the burner and the appliance.
questions.explanation: Key distinction from fan-assisted burner (3.33): forced-draft overcomes resistance of both burner AND appliance.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'certified' with respect to an appliance?

options.A: Approved by the authority having jurisdiction
options.B: Investigated and identified by a designated testing organization as conforming to recognized standards

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.36 - Certified: investigated and identified by a designated testing organization as conforming to recognized standards, requirements, or accepted test reports.
questions.explanation: Certified refers to third-party testing organization verification. Option A is the definition of 'approved' (3.12).

questions.question_text: What is a factory-built chimney?

options.A: A chimney of brick or stone constructed on site
options.B: A single-wall metal chimney constructed on site
options.C: A chimney consisting entirely of factory-made parts designed to be assembled without site fabrication
options.D: Any chimney built in a factory setting

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.38 - Factory-built chimney: a chimney that consists entirely of factory-made parts, each designed to be assembled with the other without requiring fabrication on site.
questions.explanation: Option A describes masonry or concrete chimney (3.39). The key feature is factory-made parts assembled without site fabrication.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'combustible' material?

options.B: Material that fails to conform to CAN/ULC-S114 requirements for non-combustibility
options.C: Material with a specific heat rating

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.41 - Combustible: material that fails to conform to CAN/ULC-S114 requirements for noncombustibility.
questions.explanation: The definition references specific testing standard CAN/ULC-S114. Noncombustible (3.129) is material that conforms to this standard.

questions.question_text: What is concealed piping or tubing?

options.A: Piping that passes through a wall or partition
options.B: Piping hidden from view in a finished building and can only be exposed by use of a tool

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.47 - Concealed piping or tubing: piping or tubing that, when in place in a wall, floor, or ceiling of a finished building, is hidden from view and can only be exposed by use of a tool.
questions.explanation: The key criteria are: hidden from view in finished building AND requires a tool to expose. Not just passing through walls.

questions.question_text: What is delivery pressure?

options.A: The inlet gas pressure to the appliance
options.B: The outlet gas pressure from the service regulator for natural gas or second stage propane regulator
options.C: The pressure in the distribution system
options.D: The pressure at the main burner

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.52 - Delivery pressure: the outlet gas pressure from the service regulator for natural gas or a second stage propane regulator for propane.
questions.explanation: Delivery pressure is measured at the regulator outlet, not at the appliance inlet or burner.

questions.question_text: What is design pressure?

options.A: The minimum pressure a system can handle
options.C: The maximum inlet pressure a gas piping system is capable and intended to continuously sustain under normal conditions
options.D: The pressure at the appliance inlet

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.54 - Design pressure: the maximum inlet pressure a gas piping system or valve train is capable and intended to continuously sustain, contain, or control under normal conditions.
questions.explanation: Design pressure is the maximum continuous operating pressure the system is designed for.

questions.question_text: What is a direct-fired appliance?

options.A: An appliance where combustion products are intermixed with the medium being heated
options.B: An appliance where combustion products are not mixed with the medium being heated
options.C: An appliance with direct venting to outdoors
options.D: An appliance with a sealed combustion chamber

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.55 - Direct-fired appliance: an appliance in which the combustion products or flue gases are intermixed with the medium being heated.
questions.explanation: Option B describes indirect-fired appliance (3.114). Option C describes direct-vent appliance (3.56), which is different.

questions.question_text: What is an indirect-fired appliance?

options.A: An appliance where flue gases are mixed with the medium being heated
options.B: An appliance where combustion products or flue gases are not mixed within the appliance with the medium being heated
options.C: An appliance that requires indirect venting
options.D: An appliance with an indirect ignition system

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.114 - Indirect-fired appliance: an appliance in which the combustion products or flue gases are not mixed within the appliance with the medium that is being heated.
questions.explanation: Option A describes direct-fired appliance (3.55). Heat is transferred through a heat exchanger, keeping combustion products separate.

questions.question_text: What is natural draft?

options.A: Draft produced by a fan or blower
options.B: Draft produced upstream from the combustion zone
options.C: A draft other than a mechanical draft
options.D: Draft produced by a mechanical aspirator

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.63 - Natural draft: a draft other than a mechanical draft.
questions.explanation: Natural draft relies on buoyancy of hot flue gases rising. Options A, B, and D all describe mechanical draft variations (3.60).

questions.question_text: What is a drip pocket?

options.A: A pocket designed for collection of dirt
options.B: A pocket in a piping system designed for collection of condensate

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.67 - Drip pocket (drip): a pocket in a piping system designed for the collection of condensate and from which the condensate can be removed.
questions.explanation: A drip pocket collects condensate (moisture) from gas piping, not dirt or debris.

questions.question_text: What is a dwelling unit?

options.B: A housekeeping unit used as a domicile containing cooking, eating, living, sleeping, and sanitary facilities
options.D: A single room used for living

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.68 - Dwelling unit: a housekeeping unit used or intended to be used as a domicile by one or more persons, and usually containing cooking, eating, living, sleeping, and sanitary facilities.
questions.explanation: A dwelling unit must have the essential facilities for independent living: cooking, eating, living, sleeping, and sanitary facilities.

questions.question_text: What is a fan-assisted combustion system?

options.A: An appliance with natural draft enhanced by a fan
options.B: An appliance equipped with integral mechanical means to draw or force products of combustion through combustion chamber and/or heat exchanger
options.C: An appliance with a draft hood and fan
options.D: An appliance with external mechanical draft

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.76 - Fan-assisted combustion system: an appliance equipped with an integral mechanical means to either draw or force products of combustion through the combustion chamber and/or heat exchanger.
questions.explanation: Key word is 'integral' - the fan is built into the appliance. Option D describes an external power venter which is different.

questions.question_text: What is a flue collar?

options.A: The portion of an appliance designed for attachment of a draft hood, vent connector, or venting system
options.B: A collar used to seal the flue pipe
options.C: A decorative collar around the flue
options.D: A safety device on the flue pipe

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.89 - Flue collar: that portion of an appliance designed for the attachment of a draft hood, vent connector, or venting system.
questions.explanation: The flue collar is the connection point on the appliance for attaching venting components.

questions.question_text: What is an automatic flue damper?

options.A: A damper that must be manually adjusted
options.B: A flue damper designed to fully open before ignition and interlocked to close gas supply or fall fully open upon loss of driving medium
options.C: A damper that partially closes during operation
options.D: A damper that operates only when the appliance is off

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.91 - Automatic flue damper: a flue damper that is designed to fully open the venting system automatically before ignition of the main burner and is either interlocked to automatically close off the supply of gas to the appliance or provided with means to ensure that the damper will fall fully open upon loss of the driving medium.
questions.explanation: Safety feature: must open before ignition and fail to open position if driving medium is lost.

questions.question_text: What is a gas connector?

options.A: Any pipe connecting gas supply to appliance
options.B: A factory-fabricated assembly consisting of gas conduit and fittings designed to convey fuel from supply piping to appliance gas inlet

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.99 - Gas connector: a factory-fabricated assembly consisting of gas conduit and related fittings designed to convey gaseous fuel from a gas supply piping to the gas inlet of an appliance.
questions.explanation: Key requirement: factory-fabricated assembly. Not field-assembled piping.

questions.question_text: What is a gas convenience outlet?

options.B: A permanently mounted hand-operated device with integral manually operated gas valve and thermal shut-off

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.100 - Gas convenience outlet: a permanently mounted hand-operated device that is certified to CSA/ANSI 221.90/CSA 6.24 providing a means for connecting and disconnecting an appliance to the gas supply piping by way of a gas hose or gas connector.
questions.explanation: The question's option B mentions thermal shut-off which aligns with the safety features of certified convenience outlets. Must be certified to specific standard.

questions.question_text: What is a heat reclaimer?

options.A: A device to reclaim heat from combustion air
options.B: A device installed externally or internally to a venting system to extract heat from flue gases

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.103 - Heat reclaimer: a device installed either externally or internally to a venting system to extract heat from flue gases.
questions.explanation: Heat reclaimers recover waste heat from flue gases, not combustion air. Location can be internal or external to venting system.

questions.question_text: What is a construction heater?

options.A: A permanent heating system for buildings
options.B: A portable heater intended only for temporary use in heating buildings under construction, alteration, or repair
options.C: A heater designed for outdoor use only

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.105 - Construction heater: a portable heater intended only for temporary use in heating buildings under construction, alteration, or repair.
questions.explanation: Key characteristics: portable, temporary use, for buildings under construction/alteration/repair.

questions.question_text: What is interrupted ignition?

options.A: A source of ignition that continues during the entire period that flame is present
options.B: A source of ignition that ceases to function after the trial-for-ignition period
options.C: An ignition source that operates continuously
options.D: An ignition source that requires manual activation

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.113 - Interrupted ignition: a source of ignition that ceases to function after the trial-for-ignition period.
questions.explanation: Interrupted ignition stops after the trial-for-ignition period. Option A describes direct ignition that continues while flame is present.

questions.question_text: What is a lock-up regulator?

options.A: A regulator that locks in a fixed position
options.B: A feature of a pressure regulator capable of maintaining reduced outlet pressure when fuel flow condition is static
options.C: A regulator that requires a key to adjust
options.D: A regulator that automatically shuts off

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.117 - Lock-up (positive shut-off): a feature of a pressure regulator that is capable of maintaining a reduced outlet pressure when the fuel flow condition is static. Section 3.150 - Lock-up regulator: a regulator capable of maintaining reduced outlet pressure when fuel flow is static.
questions.explanation: Lock-up refers to maintaining outlet pressure when there is no gas flow (static condition). Not about physical locking or shutting off.

questions.question_text: What is a lubricated-plug-type valve?

options.B: A manually operated valve of plug and barrel type with means for maintaining lubricant between bearing surfaces

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.186 - Lubricated-plug-type valve: a manually operated valve of the plug and barrel type that is provided with means for maintaining a lubricant between its bearing surfaces.
questions.explanation: Specific type: manually operated, plug and barrel design, with means to maintain lubricant. Quarter-turn operation.

questions.question_text: What is maximum operating pressure?

options.B: The maximum pressure to which any component or portion of the fuel system can be subjected
options.C: The design pressure of the system
options.D: The delivery pressure to the appliance

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.118 - Maximum operating pressure: the maximum pressure to which any component or portion of the fuel system can be subjected.
questions.explanation: Different from design pressure (3.54) which is continuous normal operation. Maximum operating pressure is the highest pressure any component may see.

questions.question_text: What is a mobile home?

options.B: A dwelling consisting of a vehicular portable structure built on a chassis designed for use with or without permanent foundation

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.120 - Mobile home: a dwelling that consists of a vehicular portable structure built on a chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation and to be connected to indicated utilities.
questions.explanation: Key elements: dwelling (not just any moveable structure), built on chassis, designed for use with/without permanent foundation.

questions.question_text: What is an operating control?

options.B: A control used to regulate or control the normal operation of an appliance

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.131 - Operating control: a control used to regulate or control the normal operation of an appliance.
questions.explanation: Operating controls manage normal appliance function (like thermostats). Safety devices and limit controls are separate categories.

questions.question_text: What is a monitoring regulator?

options.A: A regulator that displays pressure readings
options.B: An overpressure protection device that functions as a second gas pressure regulator in series with the primary regulator
options.C: A regulator that monitors gas flow

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.133 - Monitoring regulator: an overpressure protection device that functions as a second gas pressure regulator in series with the primary gas pressure regulator.
questions.explanation: A monitoring regulator provides overpressure protection by having a secondary regulator ready to take over if primary fails.

questions.question_text: What is an overpressure shut-off device?

options.A: A device that relieves excess pressure
options.C: An overpressure protection device that functions by completely shutting off the flow of gas into the downstream system

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.135 - Overpressure shut-off device: an overpressure protection device that functions by completely shutting off the flow of gas into the downstream system.
questions.explanation: Unlike a relief valve that vents excess pressure, this device completely shuts off gas flow when overpressure occurs.

questions.question_text: What is a proved pilot?

options.A: A pilot that has been tested and certified
options.B: A pilot flame supervised by a primary safety control that senses presence of pilot prior to gas being admitted to main burner

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.141 - Proved pilot: a pilot flame supervised by a primary safety control that senses the presence of the pilot prior to gas being admitted to the main burner.
questions.explanation: A proved pilot ensures pilot flame exists before allowing main burner gas. This is a safety feature, not about certification.

questions.question_text: What is a power venter?

options.A: A built-in fan in the appliance
options.B: A field-installed device that provides mechanical draft located between appliance flue outlet and vent termination

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.145 - Power venter: a field-installed device that provides mechanical draft and, when installed, is located between the appliance flue outlet or draft-control device and the vent or chimney termination, or at the vent or chimney termination.
questions.explanation: Key distinction: field-installed (not built-in like fan-assisted combustion system). Located in venting system, not at burner.

questions.question_text: What is a service regulator?

options.C: A pressure regulator installed on a service line to control the pressure of gas delivered to the customer

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.151 - Service regulator: a pressure regulator installed on a service line to control the pressure of the gas delivered to the customer.
questions.explanation: Service regulator is typically at the meter, controlling pressure delivered to customer premises.

questions.question_text: What is a quick-disconnect device?

options.B: A hand-operated device for connecting/disconnecting with automatic shut-off when disconnected, certified to CSA/ANSI 221.41/CSA 6.9

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.155 - Quick-disconnect device: a hand-operated device that is used for connecting and disconnecting an appliance or a hose or certain types of gas connectors to a gas supply, that is equipped with an automatic means to shut off the gas supply when the device is disconnected, and that is certified to CSA/ANSI 221.41/CSA 6.9.
questions.explanation: Must have automatic shut-off when disconnected and be certified to specific standard. Not just any quick connection.

questions.question_text: What does 'readily accessible' mean?

options.C: Capable of being reached quickly without climbing over obstacles, removal of obstacles, or use of portable ladder

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.157 - Readily accessible: capable of being reached quickly for operation, renewal, servicing, or inspection, without requiring climbing over, or the removal of, an obstacle or the use of a portable ladder.
questions.explanation: Key criteria: no climbing over obstacles, no removing obstacles, no portable ladder required. Option A contradicts the definition.

questions.question_text: What is a safety shut-off valve?

options.B: A valve that automatically shuts off gas supply when de-energized by a combustion safety control or loss of actuating medium

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.188 - Safety shut-off valve: a valve that automatically shuts off the supply of gas when de-energized by a combustion safety control, safety limit control, or loss of actuating medium.
questions.explanation: Key feature: automatic operation in response to safety control signals or loss of power. Not manually operated.

questions.question_text: What is a Type B vent?

options.B: A vent complying with CAN/ULC-S605 consisting of factory-made parts for venting gas appliances

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.196 - Type B vent: a vent complying with CAN/ULC-S605 consisting entirely of factory-made parts, each designed to be assembled with the others without requiring field fabrication, and intended for venting gas appliances.
questions.explanation: Type B vent must comply with CAN/ULC-S605 standard, consist of factory-made parts, assembled without field fabrication.

questions.question_text: What is a vent connector?

options.B: That part of venting system that conducts flue gases from flue collar of appliance to chimney or vent

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.200 - Vent connector: that part of a venting system that conducts the flue gases from the flue collar of an appliance to a chimney or vent, and that may include a draft-control device.
questions.explanation: The vent connector is the portion between the appliance flue collar and the chimney/vent. Not the entire system or just a fitting.

questions.question_text: What is a special venting system?

options.B: A venting system certified with the appliance and supplied or specified by the appliance manufacturer
options.C: A venting system for special applications

questions.code_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Section 3.206 - Special venting system: a venting system certified with the appliance and either supplied or specified by the appliance manufacturer.
questions.explanation: Key requirements: certified WITH the appliance and supplied/specified by the manufacturer. Not just any custom or special-use vent.

questions.question_text: What task may a holder of a Gas Technician 3 complete with general supervision of a Gas Technician 2?

options.C: Nothing, until the G3 holder has demonstrated essential skills to the supervising certificate holder.
options.D: Any service to an appliance under 400,000 Btu

unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: Under O. Reg. 212/01, a G3 holder under general supervision of a G2 cannot perform any work until they have demonstrated essential skills to the supervising certificate holder. This ensures safe practices are established before independent or supervised work begins.

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for issuing a proof of inspection with respect to things that have been inspected and found capable of being used or operated safely?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: Under the TSSA Act, an Inspector may issue a proof of inspection with respect to things that have been inspected and found capable of being used or operated safely and may cancel such proof.

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for establishing qualifications, training and experience required for persons to whom this Act applies?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: The TSSA Director is responsible for establishing qualifications, training and experience required for persons to whom the Act applies, including gas technicians.

questions.question_text: How long is a Contractors registration valid for?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A contractor's registration is valid for 3 years under Ontario Regulation 212/01.

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for maintaining records and plans of a container refill center, including location of underground piping and tubing of the plant?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: The person who operates the plant is responsible for maintaining records and plans of a container refill center, including location of underground piping and tubing.

questions.question_text: What is the maximum input of appliance that a G2 holder may work on without any supervision?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A G2 certificate holder may work on appliances with an input of 400,000 Btu/hr or less without supervision. The limit is 400,000 Btu/hr inclusive.

questions.question_text: A Category 4 appliance is:

options.A: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure, and with a flue loss less than 17%
options.B: An appliance that operates with a non-positive vent static pressure, and with a flue loss not less than 17%
options.C: An appliance that operates with a non-positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss less than 17%
options.D: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss not less than 17%

unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 3.11: A Category IV appliance is 'an appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a flue loss less than 17%'. These are typically high-efficiency condensing appliances.

questions.question_text: A light used for searching for gas leakage shall be:
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.12.2: A light, including a flashlight, used in connection with a search for gas leakage shall be of the Class I, Group IIA type (which corresponds to Group D for combustible gases like natural gas and propane).

questions.question_text: When using a gauge to perform pressure testing of a gas piping system, the gauge shall be:

options.A: 2" in diameter, maximum range of shall exceed the test pressure by at least 15% but not more than 300%.
options.B: 3" in diameter, maximum range of shall exceed the test pressure by at least 15% but not more than 300%
options.C: 3" in diameter, maximum range of test pressure shall not exceed the test pressure by at least 15% but not more than 200%
options.D: 3" in diameter, reading in 1 PSI increments.

unit_references: Unit 8 - Introduction to Piping and Tubing Systems
questions.explanation: The gauge used for pressure testing shall be at least 3 inches in diameter and the maximum range shall exceed the test pressure by at least 15% but not more than 200%.

questions.question_text: When a vent connector from a category 1 appliance passes through an unheated space, what must be done to the vent connector?

options.B: The connector must be Type C "heavy wall"
options.C: The connector must be Type B
options.D: The connector must be type BW

unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 8.18.21: When a vent connector from a Category I appliance passes through an unheated space, that portion of the vent connector shall be either a Type B or Type L vent.

questions.question_text: What must be provided when a hose is used to transfer liquid propane from one container to another?
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 6.20.7: When a gas hose is used for transferring liquid propane from one container to another, the gas hose shall be protected by a hydrostatic relief valve located between the shut-off valves on the gas hose.

questions.question_text: Meter and service regulator installations shall be made in accordance with:
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.6.1: Meter and service regulator installations shall be in accordance with CSA Z662 (Oil and Gas Pipeline Systems).

questions.question_text: What is the minimum distance a gas service regulator outlet must terminate from an appliance vent?
unit_references: Unit 8 - Introduction to Piping and Tubing Systems
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 5.6, the vent termination from a pressure regulator must be at least 3 ft (0.9 m) from any building opening, appliance vent, or air intake.

questions.question_text: How much pressure drop is allowed for a natural gas tubing system (using copper), when using 5 PSI supply pressure?
unit_references: Unit 8 - Introduction to Piping and Tubing Systems
questions.explanation: For gas piping systems operating at pressures exceeding 14 in w.c. (approximately 0.5 PSI), the pressure drop allowed varies. For a 5 PSI system, approximately 1 PSI pressure drop (20%) is typically allowed to ensure adequate pressure at appliances.

questions.question_text: An intermittent pilot is:

options.A: A pilot that is lit each time there is a call for heat and that burns during the entire period the main burner is firing
options.B: A pilot that is lit each time there is a call for heat and that is cut off automatically at the end of the trial for ignition period of the main burner.
options.C: A pilot that burns without turndown throughout the entire time the burner is in service, whether the main burner is firing or not
options.D: A pilot flame supervised by a primary safety control that senses the presence of the pilot prior to gas being admitted to the main burner

unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 3.139: An intermittent pilot is 'a pilot that is automatically lighted each time there is a call for heat and that burns during the entire period that the main burner is firing.'

questions.question_text: Who is responsible for ensuring that the manufacturers installation instructions are left with the end user?
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.3.3: The installer shall ensure that the manufacturer's instructions supplied with the appliance are left with the user.

questions.question_text: A cylinder in use in a building (under construction) shall not be located near an ______?

options.D: Cylinders cannot be used in a building under construction

unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Cylinders in use in a building under construction shall not be located near a stairway, elevator, or means of egress, as these are critical escape routes in an emergency.

questions.question_text: Every storage tank of _______ USWG capacity and over shall be provided with a pressure gauge.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Storage tanks of 2000 USWG capacity and over shall be provided with a pressure gauge to monitor tank pressure.

questions.question_text: Horizontal tanks with a capacity greater than 2000 USWG shall have a space of not less than _______inches between the underside of the tank and grade level.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Horizontal tanks with a capacity greater than 2000 USWG shall have a space of not less than 18 inches between the underside of the tank and grade level.

questions.question_text: The minimum size of an access opening to where an appliance is located is?
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.14.3: An access opening with minimum dimensions of 24 x 30 in (610 x 760 mm) shall be provided to the space in which an appliance is located.

questions.question_text: Each cylinder on a construction site shall be equipped with a __________ designed to protect the cylinder valve.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Each cylinder on a construction site shall be equipped with a collar designed to protect the cylinder valve from damage.

questions.question_text: A cylinder not connected for use shall be stored?
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Cylinders not connected for use shall be stored in a secure, upright manner to prevent tipping and valve damage.

questions.question_text: A floor of a cylinder storage room shall not be?

options.A: On any floor above ground level

unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: The floor of a cylinder storage room shall not be below grade because propane is heavier than air and would accumulate in below-grade areas, creating an explosion hazard.

questions.question_text: Propane transfer points require "NO SMOKING" signs with lettering at least _______" in height.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Propane transfer points require NO SMOKING signs with lettering at least 4 inches in height for visibility and safety.

questions.question_text: A propane dispensing device shall be located at least ______' from a property line.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: A propane dispensing device shall be located at least 10 feet from a property line for safety purposes.

questions.question_text: Propane offered for transport, and transported shall comply with?
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Propane offered for transport and transported shall comply with the Transport of Dangerous Goods Regulations as propane is classified as a dangerous good.

questions.question_text: Who has the responsibility of leaving the appliance installation instructions with the user?
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.3.3: The installer shall ensure that the manufacturer's instructions supplied with the appliance are left with the user.

questions.question_text: A ____________ cylinder shall be painted with light colours that are reflective
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Steel cylinders shall be painted with light colours that are reflective to minimize heat absorption from sunlight and reduce internal pressure buildup.

questions.question_text: Connection and disconnection of a cylinder must take place at least ______' from any source of ignition.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Connection and disconnection of a cylinder must take place at least 10 feet from any source of ignition to prevent fire or explosion hazards.

questions.question_text: A person who holds a certificate shall notify the director within _______ days after any change in his or her address
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A person who holds a certificate shall notify the director within 30 days after any change in their address.

questions.question_text: The definition of "approved appliance is:

options.A: Device that uses a hydrocarbon including all valves, fittings and controls and component attached to the device, that bears a label indicating that it meets an approved standard under any of the regulations mentioned in subsection 2(1)
options.B: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who is on site and in close proximity to a trainee and is available to assist and supervise the trainee
options.C: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who may or may not be on site but who is readily available to assist a trainee
options.D: Means a record issued by an approved training provider that indicates training received by a person

unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: An approved appliance is a device that uses a hydrocarbon including all valves, fittings and controls and component attached to the device, that bears a label indicating that it meets an approved standard.

questions.question_text: A gas technician 2 certificate allows a Technician to install, inspect, alter, purge, activate, repair, service or remove a natural gas or propane appliance that has an input of ____________ Btu/hr or less and the equipment and accessories essential to its operation
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A G2 certificate allows a technician to work on appliances with an input of 400,000 Btu/hr or less.

questions.question_text: Activate new appliance installations,2. clean and lubricate an appliance,3. reactivate a previously installed or converted appliance, 4. Clean, remove or replace a vent connector, venting or a draft control device
questions.topic: TSSA Regulations - G3 Scope of Work
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: This question appears incomplete. It relates to the scope of work permitted for G3 technicians under general supervision.

questions.question_text: Install, test, activate or purge gas piping or tubing that is less than two and one half inches in diameter or a component in a piping or tubing system to an appliance downstream of a natural gas meter or propane service valve up to an appliance control valve,2. clean and lubricate an appliance,3. Re-activate a previously installed or converted appliance, 4. Clean, remove or replace a vent connector, venting or a draft control device
questions.topic: TSSA Regulations - G3 Scope of Work
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: This question appears incomplete. It describes G3 scope of work under direct supervision of a G2.

questions.question_text: Install, test, activate or purge gas piping or tubing that is less than two and one half inches in diameter or a component in a piping or tubing system to an appliance downstream of a natural gas meter or propane service valve up to an appliance control valve,2. Install venting system on new appliance installation,3. reactivate a previously installed or converted appliance, 4. Clean, remove or replace a vent connector, venting or a draft control device
questions.topic: TSSA Regulations - G3 Scope of Work
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: This question appears incomplete. It describes variations of G3 scope of work.

questions.question_text: Install, test, activate or purge gas piping or tubing that is less than two and one half inches in diameter or a component in a piping or tubing system to an appliance downstream of a natural gas meter or propane service valve up to an appliance control valve,2. clean and lubricate an appliance,3. reactivate a previously installed or converted appliance, 4. Adjust propane and natural gas service regulators
questions.topic: TSSA Regulations - G3 Scope of Work
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: This question appears incomplete. Adjusting service regulators is NOT within G3 scope of work.

questions.question_text: The definition of "record of training" is:

options.A: Device that uses a hydrocarbon including all valves, fittings and controls and component attached to the device, that bears a label indicating that it meets an approved standard under any of the regulations mentioned in subsection 2(1)
options.B: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who is on site and in close proximity to a trainee and is available to assist and supervise the trainee
options.C: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who may or may not be on site but who is readily available to assist a trainee
options.D: Means a record issued by an approved training provider that indicates training received by a person

unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: Record of training means a record issued by an approved training provider that indicates training received by a person.

questions.question_text: A person who is the holder of a DA certificate may install, alter, purge, activate, repair, service or remove any unvented residential natural gas or propane gas appliance and its equipment or a vented refrigerator that has an input of ____________Btu/hr or less, other than a construction heater
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A DA (Domestic Appliance) certificate holder may work on unvented residential appliances with an input of 50,000 Btu/hr or less.

questions.question_text: The definition of "direct supervision" is:

options.A: Device that uses a hydrocarbon including all valves, fittings and controls and component attached to the device, that bears a label indicating that it meets an approved standard under any of the regulations mentioned in subsection 2(1)
options.B: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who is on site and in close proximity to a trainee and is available to assist and supervise the trainee
options.C: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who may or may not be on site but who is readily available to assist a trainee
options.D: Means a record issued by an approved training provider that indicates training received by a person

unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: Direct supervision means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who is on site and in close proximity to a trainee and is available to assist and supervise the trainee.

questions.question_text: What type of certificate must a person working in the field of natural gas distribution hold?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A person working in the field of natural gas distribution must hold a GPI (Gas Pipeline Inspector) certificate.

questions.question_text: An appliance shall be installed so that it is accessible for?
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.14.1: An appliance shall be installed so that it is accessible for servicing.

questions.question_text: Installers must instruct the _______ in the safe and correct operation of all appliances or equipment that they install.
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.3.2: Installers shall instruct the user in the safe and correct operation of all appliances or equipment that they install.

questions.question_text: Readily ignitable materials, including weeds and long dry grass, shall be removed from the area within _______' of a container, and this area shall be kept clear of such material at all times
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Readily ignitable materials shall be removed from the area within 10 feet of a propane container.

questions.question_text: Any construction heater connected to a cylinder is installed and used in accordance with clause _______ of CSA Standard B149.1
unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Construction heaters are covered in Clause 7.18 of CSA B149.1-25, which specifies requirements for construction heaters and torches.

questions.question_text: Any cylinder in storage shall not be exposed to temperatures in excess of _____ degrees F, an open flame, or other source of ignition.
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Cylinders in storage shall not be exposed to temperatures in excess of 125 degrees F to prevent excessive pressure buildup.

questions.question_text: Propane cylinders manufactured in Canada must adhere to standards set by?
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Propane cylinders manufactured in Canada must adhere to standards set by Transport Canada.

questions.question_text: Requalification of Refillable Propane cylinders used in Ontario must be completed in accordance with standards set fourth by?
unit_references: Unit 3 - Properties of Natural Gas and Fuels Safe Handling
questions.explanation: Requalification of refillable propane cylinders must be completed in accordance with standards set by Transport Canada.

questions.question_text: A(n) ___________ may recognize training and experience of an applicant for an authorization if the ___________ is of the opinion that such training or experience is equivalent to the requirements of this Act or the regulations
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: The Director may recognize training and experience of an applicant if the Director is of the opinion that such training or experience is equivalent to the requirements.

questions.question_text: The _____________ may serve the notice of proposal personally or by registered mail addressed to the applicant or authorization holder at the last address known
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: The Director may serve the notice of proposal personally or by registered mail.

questions.question_text: Subject to subsection 2, if a ____________ proposes to refuse to grant an authorization, or to suspend, revoke or refuse to renew an authorization, the ______________ shall serve notice of the proposal to that effect together with the written reasons, on the applicant or authorization holder
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: The Director is responsible for serving notice of proposals regarding authorization refusals, suspensions, or revocations.

questions.question_text: A ______________ may delegate in writing any of his or her powers or duties to any person subject to the restrictions, limitations and conditions set out in the delegation
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A Director may delegate in writing any of his or her powers or duties to any person.

questions.question_text: In the absence of a designated administrative authority who can appoint directors and inspectors?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: In the absence of a designated administrative authority, the Minister can appoint directors and inspectors.

questions.question_text: A ___________ may issue a proof of inspection with respect to things that have been inspected and found capable of being used or operated safely and may cancel such proof
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: An Inspector may issue a proof of inspection with respect to things that have been inspected and found capable of being used or operated safely.

questions.question_text: A document establishing their appointment shall be issued to ______________ and ____________, who shall produce it upon request
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: A document establishing their appointment shall be issued to Directors and Inspectors, who shall produce it upon request.

questions.question_text: What classification of certificate would be needed for a person who fills container, including vehicle tanks, and operate propane transfer equipment in a filling plant or container refill center?
unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: An OPI (Operator Propane Installation) certificate is needed for a person who fills containers and operates propane transfer equipment.

questions.question_text: The definition of "general supervision" is:

options.A: Device that uses a hydrocarbon including all valves, fittings and controls and component attached to the device, that bears a label indicating that it meets an approved standard under any of the regulations mentioned in subsection 2(1)
options.B: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who is on site and in close proximity to a trainee and is available to assist and supervise the trainee
options.C: Means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who may or may not be on site but who is readily available to assist a trainee
options.D: Means a record issued by an approved training provider that indicates training received by a person

unit_references: Unit 4a - Laws Governing the Gas Industry
questions.explanation: General supervision means supervision by a supervising certificate holder who may or may not be on site but who is readily available to assist a trainee.

questions.question_text: The minimum clearances from combustible material for a forced air furnace converted to gas shall be?

options.A: Top (casing, bonnet or plenum) 1", jacket sides and rear 6", front 24"
options.B: Top (casing, bonnet or plenum) 3", jacket sides and rear 6", front 30"
options.C: Top (casing, bonnet or plenum) 2", jacket sides and rear 4", front 24"
options.D: Top (casing, bonnet or plenum) 3", jacket sides and rear 3", front 30"

unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 7.6.1, minimum clearances for a converted forced air furnace are: Top 1 inch, sides and rear 6 inches, front 24 inches.

questions.question_text: When a pool heater is installed, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the heater to provide maintenance for the heater in accordance with the manufacturers instructions, but in no case less than _________ annually
unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 7.26.8: The owner shall provide maintenance in accordance with manufacturer's instructions, but in no case less than once annually.

questions.question_text: An appliance installed in a dwelling unit shall not be connected to a flue serving?

options.D: Appliances are not allowed to be vented into a flue

unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 8.12.3: An appliance installed in a dwelling unit shall not be connected to a flue serving a solid-fuelled appliance.

questions.question_text: A draft hood shall not be used on an appliance with ______________ draft
unit_references: Unit 9 - Introduction to Gas Appliances
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 8.23.2: A draft hood shall not be used on an appliance with either positive over-fire draft or an induced draft.

questions.question_text: Where a conflict exists between the manufacturer's certified installation instructions and this code?

options.A: The requirements of this code shall prevail unless otherwise approved
options.B: The most stringent of the two shall prevail
options.C: TSSA field approval must be obtained for the installation
options.D: Ministry of fuels field approval must be obtained for the installation

unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.1.5: Where a conflict exists between the manufacturer's instructions and this Code, the requirements of this Code shall prevail unless otherwise approved.

questions.question_text: The installation of gas burning appliances and supply piping in mobile homes shall be in accordance with?
unit_references: Unit 4 - Code and Regs
questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.8.1: The installation of gas-burning appliances and the gas piping system in mobile homes shall be in accordance with CSA Z240.4.1.

questions.question_text: What type of circuit has a complete path for the flow of electric current?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: A closed circuit has a complete path for the flow of electric current, allowing electricity to flow from source through load and back to source.

questions.question_text: What effect would an increase in current flow through a conductor have on the magnetic field around a conductor?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: An increase in current flow through a conductor increases the magnetic field around it, as the magnetic field strength is directly proportional to current.

questions.question_text: Of the following, which wire would have the smallest diameter?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: In AWG (American Wire Gauge), higher numbers indicate smaller wire diameters. AWG 18 has the smallest diameter of the options listed.

questions.question_text: Of the following, which wire would be rated to carry the most current?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: AWG 10 has the largest diameter and therefore can carry the most current. Lower AWG numbers indicate larger wire diameter and higher current capacity.

questions.question_text: Which of the following wires is rated for use on a 15 amp circuit?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: AWG 14 wire is rated for use on 15 amp circuits per the Canadian Electrical Code.

questions.question_text: In a resistive circuit, if the voltage remained constant as the resistance was increased, what effect would there be on the flow of current?

options.C: current flow would stay the same
options.D: Name the particle in an atom that has a positive charge.

unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: Per Ohm's Law (I=V/R), if voltage remains constant and resistance increases, current flow will decrease.

questions.question_text: What are materials called that do not readily produce free electrons?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: Insulators are materials that do not readily produce free electrons and therefore resist the flow of electrical current.

questions.question_text: When would an atom be considered electrically neutral?

options.A: when it contains more protons than electrons
options.B: when it contains less protons than electrons
options.C: when it contains more electrons than protons
options.D: when it contains the same number of protons as electrons

unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: An atom is electrically neutral when it contains the same number of protons (positive charges) as electrons (negative charges).

questions.question_text: Electromotive force is another term for which of the following?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: Electromotive force (EMF) is another term for voltage, which is the electrical pressure that causes current to flow.

questions.question_text: What is the unit of measurement for resistance?

options.A: the unit of measurement is the Ampere (a)
options.B: the unit of measurement is the Volt (v)
options.C: the unit of measurement is the Ohm

unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: The unit of measurement for resistance is the Ohm, named after Georg Ohm.

questions.question_text: Name the particle in an atom that has a negative charge?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: The electron is the particle in an atom that has a negative charge.

questions.question_text: Name the particle in an atom that has a neutral charge?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: The neutron is the particle in an atom that has a neutral (no) charge.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the electrical test instrument used to check for voltage or potential difference?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: A voltmeter is used to check for voltage or potential difference in an electrical circuit.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the electrical test instrument used to check for amperage?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: An ammeter is used to check for amperage (current flow) in an electrical circuit.

questions.question_text: What is the name of the electrical test instrument used to check for resistance?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: An ohmmeter is used to check for resistance in an electrical circuit or component.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between direct and alternating current?

options.A: dc current flows in one direction only - ac changes direction periodically
options.B: ac current flows in one direction only - dc changes direction periodically
options.D: List three components of a simple circuit.

unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: DC (direct current) flows in one direction only, while AC (alternating current) changes direction periodically (typically 60 times per second in North America).

questions.question_text: What is the difference between a series and a parallel circuit?

options.A: a parallel circuit has only one path for current flow and a series circuit has more than one path for current flow
options.B: a series circuit has only one path for current flow and a parallel circuit has more than one path for current flow
options.D: When voltage is increased in a resistive circuit the current will...

unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: A series circuit has only one path for current flow, while a parallel circuit has more than one path for current flow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following transformers is one in which the secondary coil output voltage is greater than the primary coil input voltage?
unit_references: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
questions.explanation: A step-up transformer has a secondary coil output voltage greater than the primary coil input voltage. It increases voltage while decreasing current.

questions.question_text: Which of the following transformers is one in which the secondary coil output voltage is less than the primary coil input voltage?
questions.explanation: A step-down transformer reduces voltage from primary to secondary. The secondary coil has fewer turns than the primary coil, resulting in lower output voltage. This is the opposite of a step-up transformer which increases voltage.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
references.training_content: CSA Gas Trade Ed7 electricity fundamentals - transformer types and operation

questions.question_text: Which of the following transformers is a power transformer that shares a winding or a portion of a winding?
questions.explanation: An autotransformer is a transformer with a single winding that is common to both primary and secondary circuits. Part of the winding serves both functions, making it more efficient for certain applications but providing less electrical isolation.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
references.training_content: CSA Gas Trade Ed7 electricity fundamentals

questions.question_text: What is the equivalent resistance of two 20 resistors connected in series?
questions.explanation: In a series circuit, resistances add directly: R_total = R1 + R2. Therefore, 20 ohms + 20 ohms = 40 ohms. Series circuits have a single path for current flow, so total resistance is the sum of all individual resistances.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What is the equivalent resistance of two 10 resistors connected in parallel?
questions.explanation: In a parallel circuit with equal resistors: R_total = R/n where n is the number of resistors. For two 10-ohm resistors: 10/2 = 5 ohms. Using the formula 1/R_total = 1/R1 + 1/R2: 1/R_total = 1/10 + 1/10 = 2/10, so R_total = 5 ohms.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity
references.training_content: Ohm's Law and parallel circuit calculations

questions.question_text: If a voltage drop were measured across a closed switch, what would this indicate?

options.B: the contacts of the switch may be dirty

questions.explanation: A properly functioning closed switch should have zero or near-zero voltage drop across it. If voltage is measured across a closed switch, it indicates resistance in the switch, typically caused by dirty, pitted, or corroded contacts that impede current flow.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What is the unit of measurement for "Difference in Potential"?

options.A: the unit of measurement is the Ampere (a)
options.B: the unit of measurement is the Volt (v)
options.C: the unit of measurement is the Ohm

questions.explanation: Difference in potential (voltage) is measured in Volts (V). Voltage is the electrical pressure or force that causes electrons to flow. Amperes measure current flow, and Ohms measure resistance.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What is the unit of measurement for "Rate of Current Flow"?

options.A: the unit of measurement is the Ampere (a)
options.B: the unit of measurement is the Volt (v)
options.C: the unit of measurement is the Ohm

questions.explanation: Current flow (the rate at which electrons flow through a conductor) is measured in Amperes (A). One ampere equals one coulomb of charge passing a point per second.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What does the sum of the voltage drops across the loads or resistances of a closed series circuit equal?

options.A: the total current of the circuit
options.B: the total voltage applied to the circuit
options.C: the total resistance of the circuit
options.D: The voltage across all branches of a parallel circuit is....

questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltage drops in a closed series circuit equals the total applied voltage. This is a fundamental principle of circuit analysis - all source voltage is consumed by the loads in the circuit.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: How much current is required to operate a 1500-watt electric heater supplied with 120 volts?
questions.explanation: Using the power formula P = V x I, rearranged to I = P/V: Current = 1500 watts / 120 volts = 12.5 amps. The closest answer is 12 amps (option B). Note: The calculated value is actually 12.5A, but 12A is the available option.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Current flow would be greatest through which of the following resistors when connected in a parallel circuit?
questions.explanation: In a parallel circuit, all branches have the same voltage. Using Ohm's Law (I = V/R), lower resistance means higher current. The 10-ohm resistor has the lowest resistance, so it will have the greatest current flow.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Power is measured in which of the following units?
questions.explanation: Electrical power is measured in Watts (W). Power = Voltage x Current (P = V x I). Amps measure current, Volts measure voltage/potential difference, and Ohms measure resistance.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: One horsepower is equal to how many watts?
questions.explanation: One mechanical horsepower equals 746 watts (745.7 watts precisely). This is a standard conversion factor used in HVAC and motor calculations.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What would be the output in Btu/h of an electric heater rated at 10 kw?
questions.explanation: 1 kW = 3,412 Btu/h. Therefore, 10 kW x 3,412 = 34,120 Btu/h, approximately 34,100 Btu/h. This conversion is essential for comparing electric and gas heating equipment.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: One watt is equal to how many Btuh?
questions.explanation: 1 Watt = 3.412 Btu/h (commonly rounded to 3.41 Btu/h). This is the standard conversion factor between electrical power (watts) and thermal energy rate (Btu/h).

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.note: Question appears incomplete in source - no options provided

questions.question_text: What would be the output in kilowatts of a heater that has a 230 volt supply drawing 20 amps?
questions.explanation: Power = Voltage x Current. P = 230V x 20A = 4,600 watts = 4.6 kW.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.note: Question appears incomplete in source - no options provided

questions.question_text: 6 Kw
questions.explanation: This question appears incomplete. The question text '6 Kw' and options don't form a coherent question. Likely a data extraction error from the source document.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: When drawing wires into a junction box you must ensure that the wires extend into the junction box by how many inches?
questions.explanation: Per the Canadian Electrical Code, conductors entering a junction box must extend at least 6 inches (150mm) into the box to allow for proper connections and serviceability.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Which of the following wire colours usually identify neutral wires?
questions.explanation: In North American electrical systems, white (or gray) wires identify the neutral conductor. Black and red are hot (line) conductors, and green (or bare copper) is the ground.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Which of the following screw terminal colours normally designate line connections on a 120v light bulb base or receptacle?
questions.explanation: Brass (gold-colored) screw terminals are used for hot/line connections. Silver terminals are for neutral connections, and green terminals are for ground connections.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Which of the following screw terminal colours normally designate neutral connections on a 120v light bulb base or receptacle?
questions.explanation: Silver screw terminals are used for neutral wire connections. The silver terminal connects to the white (neutral) wire, while brass connects to the hot wire.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: Which of the following screw terminal colours normally designate ground connections on a 120v light bulb base or receptacle?
questions.explanation: Green screw terminals are used for ground (earth) connections. The green terminal connects to the green or bare copper grounding wire.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What does this symbol indicate "" ?
questions.explanation: The infinity symbol on an ohmmeter indicates very high or infinite resistance, meaning an open circuit with no path for current flow. This typically indicates a break in the circuit or open component.

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.note: Symbol not rendered in source text

questions.question_text: What is the Btuh output of a heater rated at 20 kW?
questions.explanation: 1 kW = 3,412 Btu/h. Therefore, 20 kW x 3,412 = 68,240 Btu/h, approximately 68,200 Btu/h (closest option).

csa_units: Unit 5 - Introduction to Electricity

questions.question_text: What is the name given to a list that indicates the material required to complete an appliance installation?
questions.explanation: A bill of materials (BOM) is a comprehensive list of parts, components, and materials needed to complete an installation or assembly project. It typically includes quantities and specifications.

csa_units: Unit 6 - Technical Manuals, Specs, Drawings and Graphs

questions.question_text: What are orthographic drawings?

options.A: drawings showing individual views of front, rear, sides, top, and bottom of object
options.B: drawings that compare a number of items
options.C: drawings that show how something is related to time

questions.explanation: Orthographic drawings (also called orthographic projections) show an object from multiple perpendicular views - front, rear, left side, right side, top, and bottom - without perspective distortion.

csa_units: Unit 6 - Technical Manuals, Specs, Drawings and Graphs

questions.question_text: What do assembly drawings show?

options.A: electrical components and their related connections
options.B: several sides of an object at the same time
options.C: necessary parts needed to assemble a product and how they fit together

questions.explanation: Assembly drawings show all the parts needed to assemble a product and how they fit together. They typically include exploded views, part numbers, and assembly sequence information.

csa_units: Unit 6 - Technical Manuals, Specs, Drawings and Graphs

questions.question_text: What do pictorial drawings show?

options.A: electrical components and their related connections
options.B: several sides of an object at the same time
options.C: necessary parts needed to assemble a product and how they fit together

questions.explanation: Pictorial drawings show several sides of an object simultaneously in a single view, giving a three-dimensional appearance. Types include isometric, oblique, and perspective drawings.

csa_units: Unit 6 - Technical Manuals, Specs, Drawings and Graphs

questions.question_text: Where would you find information about a specific gas-fired appliance such as: the name of the manufacturer, the appliance input in Btu/h, the fan size, voltage and fuse information, and appliance physical dimensions?
questions.explanation: Appliance manufacturer's literature (installation manual, specification sheets, data plates) contains comprehensive information about the appliance including specifications, dimensions, electrical requirements, and installation instructions.

csa_units: Unit 6 - Technical Manuals, Specs, Drawings and Graphs

questions.question_text: What type of drawing would indicate information such as: the address of the building, equipment location, layout of piping, panel locations, duct sizing and duct layout?
