questions.explanation: Corrosion is an electrochemical process that requires four elements: an anode, a cathode, an electrolyte, and a conductive (metallic) path. If any of these four elements is absent, corrosion cannot occur.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What type of fitting is used to electrically isolate underground protected piping from aboveground unprotected piping?
questions.explanation: Dielectric fittings (such as insulated unions, insulated flanges, or insulated meter spuds) are installed directly outside the building wall to prevent electrical contact between protected underground piping and unprotected aboveground piping, thereby preventing galvanic corrosion.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What is the maximum allowable pressure drop for a natural gas piping system operating at less than 7 inches water column?
questions.explanation: For natural gas systems operating at less than 7 inches water column, the maximum allowable pressure drop is 0.5 inch water column. This is half the allowable drop for systems operating at 7-14 in w.c.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: Steel pipe fittings used in gas systems must be constructed of which materials?
questions.explanation: Steel pipe fittings must be of malleable iron or steel construction and be approved for use with gas systems. Cast iron is not acceptable for gas fittings due to its brittleness.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: Which type of manual shut-off valve is approved ONLY for indoor use?
questions.explanation: Spring-loaded plug valves are made of brass and are approved only for indoor use with sizes up to 1-inch diameter. Lubricated plug valves and ball-type valves are approved for both indoor and outdoor use.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: According to CSA B149.1, what information must be included on a pressure test tag after testing is complete?

options.A: Gas meter serial number and utility company name
options.B: Appliance model numbers and BTU ratings
options.C: Fitter's name, certificate number, and classification
options.D: Building permit number and inspector signature

questions.explanation: The test tag must include: address, contractor's name and registration number, date of test, test pressure, test duration, total pipe length, pipe size, fitter's name, fitter's certificate number and classification, and the statement 'Do not remove.'
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of performing a meter valve seepage test before pressure testing?

options.A: To verify the gas supply is adequate
options.B: To ensure gas seepage is not masking undetected leaks
options.D: To purge air from the system

questions.explanation: A meter valve seepage test ensures that gas seepage from the meter valve is not masking undetected gas leaks. If the valve passes gas (due to hard, dry sealing grease), the system test results would be invalid.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What is the maximum input rating of an appliance that can be purged using the pilot outlet of the appliance control valve?
questions.explanation: Appliances with an input of less than 400,000 Btu/h may be purged at the pilot outlet of the appliance control valve. This method is particularly useful for G2 technicians working with residential and small commercial appliances.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 3

questions.question_text: Which type of copper tubing CANNOT be used in gas piping systems?
questions.explanation: Type M copper tubing cannot be used in gas systems because its wall thickness is slightly less than that of Type G tubing. Only Types K, L, and G (gas grade) copper are approved for gas piping.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: When measuring pipe for cutting using the centre-to-centre method, what must the gas technician account for?
questions.explanation: When measuring pipe for cutting, the gas technician must account for the length of pipe that will be concealed by fittings. This concealed length is called the 'fitting allowance' and varies by pipe size and fitting type.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: A close nipple is a prohibited fitting in gas piping systems. What is a close nipple?

options.A: A nipple with threads extending the entire length
options.B: A nipple less than 2 inches in diameter
options.D: A nipple with only one end threaded

questions.explanation: A close nipple is a short pipe nipple that is threaded along its entire length, leaving no unthreaded portion. This creates a weak point where the pipe could crack or fail under stress, which is why they are prohibited in gas systems.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the minimum spacing between horizontal piping supports for 1-inch steel pipe?
questions.explanation: According to code requirements, the maximum spacing of supports for 1-inch horizontal steel piping is 8 feet. Support spacing requirements vary based on pipe size, with larger pipes requiring closer spacing.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: At what nominal pipe size must steel gas piping joints be welded rather than threaded?
questions.explanation: Steel piping NPS 4 and larger requires welded joints. Smaller diameter piping may use threaded connections. This requirement ensures adequate joint strength for larger diameter piping.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the minimum melting temperature that defines a hard solder (brazing) joint for copper tubing?
questions.explanation: Hard soldering (silver brazing) uses alloys with a melting temperature above 1000 degrees F (537 degrees C). This provides a stronger joint than soft soldering and is required for gas piping connections.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 5

questions.question_text: When an appliance outlet is not connected during installation, how must it be sealed?

options.B: With a cap or plug of compatible material
options.C: By closing the upstream valve only
options.D: It does not need to be sealed

questions.explanation: During any period when an appliance is not connected to a piping outlet, the outlet must be made gas-tight using a cap or plug made from a material compatible with the piping or tubing system.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a drip pocket in a gas piping system?

options.B: To collect and allow removal of condensate

questions.explanation: A drip pocket (also called a drip leg or sediment trap) is an area in a piping system that collects condensate and from which condensate can be removed. This protects appliance controls from moisture and debris.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: According to code, what must control the gas supply to an underground plastic pipe or tubing?

options.A: A pressure regulator at the supply
options.B: A shut-off valve situated above ground
options.C: A check valve at the meter

questions.explanation: The gas supply to underground plastic pipe or tubing shall be controlled by a shut-off valve situated above ground. This allows for safe isolation of the underground portion of the system.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: A homeowner asks if they can connect a vented appliance (furnace) to the gas supply using a flexible hose. What is the correct response?

options.A: Yes, if the hose is CSA approved
options.B: Yes, if the hose is less than 6 feet long
options.C: No, vented appliances cannot be connected with a hose
options.D: Yes, if the appliance is less than 100,000 Btu/h

questions.explanation: Vented appliances (such as furnaces, boilers, and water heaters) cannot be connected with a hose. Flexible connectors may only be used for certain unvented or movable appliances as specified in the code.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What are the pressure test requirements for a 250-foot natural gas piping system with a working pressure of 2 psig?
questions.explanation: According to Table 6.3 of CSA B149.1, a piping system with a working pressure of 2 psig and 250 feet of pipe requires a test pressure of 15 psig for 60 minutes (1 hour) duration.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What is the minimum test pressure and duration for all wrapped or factory-coated underground piping?

options.A: 15 psig within the time duration of Table 6.3
options.C: 100 psig within the time duration of Table 6.3

questions.explanation: All wrapped or factory-coated piping must be tested at a minimum of 100 psig within the time duration required by Table 6.3. This higher test pressure ensures the integrity of the protective coating.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: Can rooftop gas piping be supported using treated wood blocks?

options.A: Yes, if the blocks are pressure-treated
options.B: Yes, if the blocks are at least 4 inches thick
options.C: No, wood blocks are not permitted for rooftop piping supports
options.D: Yes, if approved by the building inspector

questions.explanation: Rooftop piping may not be supported with treated wood blocks. Piping supports must be of non-combustible material suitable for the outdoor environment and designed to prevent damage to the roof membrane.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: Can plastic pipe be used for a liquid propane gas system?

options.A: Yes, if the system pressure is less than 5 psig
options.B: Yes, if the pipe is rated for propane use
options.C: No, plastic pipe cannot be used for propane systems
options.D: Yes, but only for underground portions

questions.explanation: Plastic pipe cannot be used on liquid propane systems. Propane can damage certain plastics and the system pressures involved require metal piping. Polyethylene may only be used for natural gas underground.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: Under what circumstances can piping smaller than NPS 1/2 be used indoors for propane?

options.A: Never - 1/2 inch is the minimum indoor size
options.B: On a branch line if it is 1/4 inch and not exceeding 15 feet
options.C: On a branch line if it is 3/8 inch and not exceeding 25 feet
options.D: Only if the appliance input is less than 50,000 Btu/h

questions.explanation: Piping less than NPS 1/2 may be used indoors on a propane branch line if it is 1/4 inch and does not exceed 15 feet in length. This exception accommodates smaller appliance connections.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: Can propane piping or tubing be supported by other piping or tubing?

options.A: Yes, if the supporting pipe is larger in diameter
options.B: Yes, if the propane tubing is less than NPS 3/4
options.C: No, propane piping must have independent supports
options.D: Yes, if both pipes are made of the same material

questions.explanation: Propane piping or tubing shall not be supported by other piping or tubing. Each gas line requires independent supports to prevent stress transfer and ensure proper support throughout the installation.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the required diameter of a drip pocket (dirt pocket) for a propane system?

options.B: NPS 2 or equal to the diameter of the pipe it serves, whichever is less
options.C: NPS 2 or equal to the diameter of the pipe it serves, whichever is greater
options.D: Equal to the diameter of the pipe it serves

questions.explanation: For propane systems, the drip pocket diameter shall be NPS 2 or equal to the diameter of the pipe it serves, whichever is less. This ensures adequate capacity for collecting debris and condensate.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: When copper tubing runs horizontally through notched studs, what protection is required at each stud?
questions.explanation: When tubing runs horizontally across studs notched to accommodate the tubing, it must be protected where it crosses each stud by a 16-gauge (USG) steel plate. This protects against nail or screw penetration.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the maximum interval that propane tubing can run without identification inside a residential occupancy?
questions.explanation: Propane tubing inside a residential occupancy must be identified at intervals not exceeding 6 feet. This identification helps ensure the tubing can be easily recognized as a gas line.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: When propane piping is extended from one building to another, where must shut-off valves be positioned?

options.A: At the exit of the first building only
options.B: At the entry of the second building only
options.C: At both the exit of the first building and entry of the second building

questions.explanation: When propane piping or tubing is extended from one building to another, shut-off valves must be installed at both locations: one at the exit of the first building and another at the point of entry to the second building.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What are the required test pressure and duration for a propane piping system 50 feet long with a working pressure of 10 psig?
questions.explanation: According to Table 6.3, a propane piping system of 50 feet with a working pressure of 10 psig requires testing at 50 psig (5 times working pressure) for 60 minutes duration.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: Is an individual shut-off valve required for each propane appliance in a recreational vehicle?

options.A: No, only the main supply valve is required
options.B: Yes, all propane appliances in an RV require individual shut-off valves
options.D: Only if there are more than two appliances

questions.explanation: An individual shut-off valve is required for all propane appliances on a recreational vehicle. This allows for isolation of individual appliances for service or in case of a leak.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the function of an eccentric plug valve?

options.C: To provide tight shut-off with reduced operating torque
options.D: To filter debris from the gas

questions.explanation: An eccentric plug valve has a spherically faced plug that rotates approximately 50 degrees, with the eccentric motion reducing operating torque. The absence of sliding friction between plug and seat reduces wear and provides tight shut-off.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What type of valve is typically used for smaller applications and internal valve control, and is operated with a screwdriver?
questions.explanation: Needle valves are used for smaller applications and internal valve control. They are simple flow restrictors that are usually opened or closed using a screwdriver. When slightly unscrewed, flow is limited; full flow occurs when fully unscrewed.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: According to CSA B149.1, where must a master shut-off valve be installed when multiple gas outlets are in a classroom or laboratory?

options.B: In a readily accessible location that is easy to identify
options.C: In a locked cabinet accessible only to staff

questions.explanation: When multiple outlets are installed in a classroom, laboratory, or similar facility, they must be able to be controlled via an easy-to-identify master shut-off valve in a readily accessible location.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: A gas technician is installing copper tubing for a residential furnace. What type of joint is required for gas piping connections?
questions.explanation: Gas piping connections using copper tubing require hard solder (brazing) joints with a melting temperature above 1000 degrees F (537 degrees C). Soft solder joints are not permitted for gas piping.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 5

questions.question_text: How should a leak be located if a pressure drop indicates a leak during testing?

options.B: By using a flame to detect escaping gas
options.C: By applying leak detector solution to joints
options.D: By observing the pressure gauge for fluctuations

questions.explanation: If a pressure drop indicates a leak, perform a 'soap test' by applying leak detector solution to each joint or fitting in the suspect portion of the system. A leak will cause the solution to bubble at its source.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What is the required calibration for a pressure gauge used to test systems with working pressure exceeding 0.5 psig but not exceeding 5 psig?

options.A: Increments of not greater than 1 in w.c.
options.B: Increments of not greater than 2 in w.c. (0.5 kPa)
options.C: Increments of not greater than 5 in w.c.
options.D: Increments of not greater than 0.5 psig

questions.explanation: For systems where the working pressure exceeds 0.5 psig but does not exceed 5 psig, the pressure gauge shall undergo calibration to read in increments of not greater than 2 in w.c. (0.5 kPa).
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What calibration is required for a pressure gauge used to test systems with working pressure exceeding 5 psig?

options.C: 2 psig or 2% of maximum dial reading, whichever is less

questions.explanation: For systems with working pressure exceeding 5 psig, the pressure gauge shall be calibrated to read in increments of not greater than either 2 psig (14 kPa) or 2% of the maximum dial reading, whichever is less.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What must be done to components with pressure ratings below the test pressure before testing a gas piping system?

options.B: Isolate or remove them from the system
options.C: Test them separately at a lower pressure

questions.explanation: Before testing, isolate or remove any components of the system that have a pressure rating below the test pressure to prevent damage to these components during the high-pressure test.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: After appliance installation, what is the minimum time the gas pressure must be maintained during the low-pressure leak test?
questions.explanation: After appliance installation, the system is tested under normal operating pressure for a minimum of 10 minutes. If the manometer or pressure gauge indicates a leak during this time, further investigation is required.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 2

questions.question_text: What type of gas valve must be placed within 5 feet of a purge point?
questions.explanation: A quarter-turn shut-off valve must be placed within 5 feet of the purge point. This allows for quick shut-off during purging operations in case of emergency.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 3

questions.question_text: What is used to purge the air out of a gas piping system that is NPS 4 or larger in diameter?
questions.explanation: For piping systems NPS 4 or larger in diameter, an inert gas (such as nitrogen or carbon dioxide) must be used to purge the air. This prevents creating a potentially explosive air-gas mixture during purging.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 3

questions.question_text: What is 'resistivity' in relation to soil and corrosion?

options.A: The ability of soil to conduct heat
options.B: The resistance of soil to electric force within a 1 cm cube
options.C: The soil's ability to hold moisture
options.D: The chemical composition of the soil

questions.explanation: Resistivity refers to the electrolyte's (soil) resistance to electric force within a cube measuring 1 cm3. It is expressed in ohm/cm and determines how corrosive the soil is to metal piping.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: At what soil resistivity level is steel piping considered to be in especially corrosive soil?
questions.explanation: Nearly all soils are corrosive to steel, but soils below 10,000 ohms/cm are considered especially corrosive. Soils below 5,000 ohms/cm are sufficiently corrosive to cast iron or ductile iron to warrant cathodic protection.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What is the Wenner four-pin method used for?
questions.explanation: The Wenner four-pin method is used to measure soil resistivity. It involves driving four pins into the ground in a straight line, imposing a current between the outer pins, and measuring voltage across the inner pins.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What test is used to find imperfections in a protective coating on underground pipe?
questions.explanation: The holiday detector test (also known as the jeep test) is an electronic testing method that finds imperfections (holidays) in protective coatings on piping so they can be repaired before the pipe is buried.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: According to CSA B149.1, what is the requirement for bonding of building metal gas piping?

options.A: Gas piping must be used as an electrical ground
options.B: Gas piping must be electrically continuous and bonded per electrical code
options.C: Gas piping does not require bonding

questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1 Clause 4.7.3, all building metal gas piping that may become energized shall be made electrically continuous and shall be bonded in accordance with CSA C22.1 or local electrical code requirements.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: Can gas piping be used as an electrical ground?

options.A: Yes, if the piping is metal
options.B: Yes, if approved by the electrical inspector
options.C: No, CSA B149.1 forbids using gas piping as an electrical ground

questions.explanation: CSA B149.1 specifically forbids the use of gas piping as an electrical ground. While CSA C22.1 requires bonding of gas piping, bonding and grounding are different concepts with different requirements.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: Why should conventional bonding methods NOT be used on CSST (corrugated stainless steel tubing)?

options.B: It can puncture the tubing or cause arcing damage
options.C: CSST is already bonded at the factory
options.D: Bonding is not required for CSST

questions.explanation: Conventional bonding methods can create a hazardous situation where CSST can be punctured by the bonding installation or damaged by arcing between improperly secured bonding means during faults or lightning strikes.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a better electrolyte for causing corrosion?
questions.explanation: Moist soil with low resistance to electric current (such as loam or clay) is a better electrolyte than dry soil or gravel. This means piping buried in moist loamy soil is more prone to corrosion.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What are the three main methods for protecting underground steel piping from corrosion?

options.B: Protective coatings, electrical insulation, and cathodic protection
options.C: Concrete encasement, PVC sleeving, and drainage
options.D: Galvanizing, plastic coating, and depth of cover

questions.explanation: The three methods for protecting underground steel piping from corrosion are: protective coatings (which insulate from soil), electrical insulation (using dielectric fittings), and cathodic protection (using sacrificial anodes).
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 4

questions.question_text: What are the six factors that influence flow rate through a gas pipe?

options.A: Temperature, pressure, humidity, altitude, pipe material, gas type
options.B: Volume required, pressure drop, pipe length, pipe diameter, gas type, number of fittings
options.C: Inlet pressure, outlet pressure, pipe color, fitting type, gas temperature, wall thickness
options.D: Meter size, regulator type, pipe material, appliance load, ambient temperature, elevation

questions.explanation: The six factors influencing flow rate through a pipe are: volume of gas required, pressure drop, length of pipe, diameter of pipe, type of gas, and number of fittings. These must all be considered when sizing piping.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: In pipe sizing, what does LMR stand for?
questions.explanation: LMR stands for Longest Measured Run, which is the total length of piping from the meter to the farthest appliance. This measurement is used to select the appropriate Calculated Zone (CZ) for pipe sizing.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: In pipe sizing, what does CZ stand for?
questions.explanation: CZ stands for Calculated Zone. After determining the LMR, the CZ is selected from the pipe sizing tables. The CZ must equal or exceed the LMR to ensure adequate pipe capacity.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: What is the maximum pressure drop allowed for a propane piping system operating at 11 inches water column?
questions.explanation: For propane systems operating at 11 inches water column, the maximum allowable pressure drop is 1.0 inch water column. This is the same as for natural gas systems at 7-14 in w.c.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: A gas technician is sizing piping for a furnace with an input of 100,000 Btu/h and a water heater with an input of 40,000 Btu/h. What is the total load for the main supply line?
questions.explanation: The main supply line must be sized for the total connected load. In this case, 100,000 Btu/h (furnace) + 40,000 Btu/h (water heater) = 140,000 Btu/h total load.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: What determines the gas pressure requirements for an appliance?

options.A: The pipe sizing tables in Annex A
options.C: Either the appliance rating plate or the manufacturer

questions.explanation: Gas pressure requirements for an appliance shall be determined according to either the appliance rating plate or the appliance manufacturer. This ensures the appliance receives proper operating pressure.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What requirement applies to extending an existing gas piping system?

options.A: The extension must use the same pipe diameter as the existing system
options.B: The extension must be sized to meet the load demand of the extended system
options.C: The extension must be installed by a G1 technician
options.D: The existing system must be completely replaced

questions.explanation: An extension of an existing piping or tubing system shall be sized to meet the load demand of the extended piping system. This may require resizing portions of the existing system if capacity is insufficient.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: Why must the ends of all steel pipe be reamed after cutting?

options.B: To remove burrs that could restrict gas flow or damage components

questions.explanation: The ends of all piping must be reamed to remove burrs created during cutting. These burrs can restrict gas flow and can damage downstream components such as regulators and valve seats.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 1

questions.question_text: What is the colour code for Type L copper tubing?
questions.explanation: Type L copper tubing is colour-coded blue. Type K is green (thickest wall), Type L is blue (medium wall), and Type M is red (thinnest wall, not permitted for gas).
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 5

questions.question_text: A G2 technician is installing a new gas range in a residence. What must be verified about piping size before completing the installation?

options.A: The piping must match the range's connector size
options.B: The piping must be sized to meet volume and pressure requirements at the point of use
options.C: The piping must be at least NPS 3/4
options.D: The piping must be the same size as the meter outlet

questions.explanation: All piping shall be sized to meet the volume and pressure requirements at the point of use. The technician must verify that the existing piping can supply adequate gas volume to the new appliance at the required pressure.
unit_references: Unit 8 - Piping and Tubing Systems, Chapter 6

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of a Type B vent in residential gas appliance installations?

options.A: To handle high-temperature flue gases from oil appliances
options.B: To vent low-temperature flue gases from gas appliances
options.C: To provide combustion air to the appliance
options.D: To create a positive pressure venting system

questions.explanation: Type B vents are only approved for handling low-temperature gases from gas appliances. They have a double-wall construction with an aluminum inner wall and galvanized outer wall, enclosing an insulating dead air space.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: A chimney is required when flue gas temperatures exceed what temperature?
questions.explanation: Chimneys are commonly used to vent oil, solid fuel, or gas appliances with flue temperatures exceeding 470F (243C). Due to the high temperatures, these vents are made of heat-resistant materials like masonry or insulated metal.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What distinguishes a Type BW vent from a standard Type B vent?

options.A: Type BW has a stainless steel inner wall
options.B: Type BW is oval-shaped for recessed wall furnace installations
options.C: Type BW is rated for higher temperatures

questions.explanation: A Type BW vent is similar in construction to a Type B vent, except that it is oval, not round. Type BW vents are approved for recessed wall furnaces where you can install the oval shape inside a 2 x 4 stud wall.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: To which standard must plastic venting materials for high-efficiency appliances be certified?
questions.explanation: New plastic piping installations for Type BH venting must employ certified ULC S636 venting systems. Before the regulatory acceptance of ULC S636 in 2007, non-certified plastic venting was permitted but is no longer acceptable for new installations.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: How many screws are required at each joint of a single-wall vent connector?
questions.explanation: Single-wall vent sections must be secured with three screws, positioned 120 apart, at each joint. This ensures proper mechanical connection and prevents separation.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What is the main difference between a Type L vent and a Type B vent?

options.A: Type L has an aluminum inner wall
options.B: Type L has a stainless steel inner wall for better heat and corrosion resistance
options.C: Type L is only for propane appliances
options.D: Type L has no insulating air space

questions.explanation: A Type L vent is very similar to a Type B vent, except the inner wall is made of stainless steel, which makes the vent more resistant to heat and corrosion. Type L vents are typically specified when heat or corrosion may be a problem.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What is a direct-vent appliance also known as?
questions.explanation: Direct-vent appliances, also known as sealed combustion appliances, draw combustion air from the outside and vent all flue gases directly outdoors. Both the vent and combustion air intakes are integral parts of the appliance.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What conditions provide a natural-draft venting system with the greatest amount of draft?

options.A: Low stack temperature, high outdoor temperature, high stack height
options.B: High stack temperature, high outdoor temperature, low stack height
options.C: High stack temperature, low outdoor temperature, high stack height
options.D: Low stack temperature, low outdoor temperature, low stack height

questions.explanation: Natural draft is maximized when there is a high temperature difference between the flue gases and outdoor air (high stack temperature, low outdoor temperature) combined with greater stack height. This creates maximum buoyancy for the flue gases.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a concentric vent system?

options.A: To increase the temperature of flue gases
options.B: To draw in combustion air and emit flue gases from the same vent terminal
options.D: To reduce condensation in the vent system

questions.explanation: A concentric vent draws in combustion air and emits flue gases from the same vent. Some direct-vent systems use concentric air intake/exhaust vents, while others have separate air intake and exhaust pipes.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What corrosive substance forms when condensation occurs in a venting system?
questions.explanation: Corrosion occurs when condensed H2O mixes with CO2 and forms carbonic acid, which attacks the brick, chimney liner, and concrete, accelerating their deterioration.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: What component allows dilution air to enter the venting system of an atmospherically fired appliance?
questions.explanation: A draft hood allows dilution air to enter the venting system of an atmospherically fired appliance. It maintains neutral pressure over the fire and protects against downdrafts.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 1: Venting systems

questions.question_text: Which type of burner produces a single large flame?
questions.explanation: A monoport atmospheric burner produces a single large flame. These include inshot burners and upshot burners where the flame may be spread using a flame spreader.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: What is the term for a burner flame that moves back through the burner nozzle?
questions.explanation: Flashback refers to a burner flame that moves back through the burner nozzle. Monoport burners are most susceptible to flashback, and flame spreaders help prevent this condition.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: What is the recommended maximum drill size for port diameter in drilled-port atmospheric burners?
questions.explanation: Using smaller drill sizes for burner ports results in more even flame distribution. Ports should not be larger than a No. 29 drill, but to avoid plugging, they should not be smaller than a No. 42.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: What is the primary problem associated with multiport burners?
questions.explanation: Multiport burners are susceptible to internal clogging from lint. Multiple burner ports distribute flames for good heat transfer and stable blue flames, but the internal passages can collect debris.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: In a forced-draft burner system, where is the combustion air supplied from?

options.B: A fan or blower under sufficient pressure to overcome restrictions

questions.explanation: A forced-draft burner has the combustion air supplied by a fan or blower under sufficient pressure to overcome the restriction of the burner and appliance. This differs from atmospheric burners that rely on natural draft.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: How does an induced-draft burner differ from a forced-draft burner?

options.A: It has no fan or blower
options.B: The fan is located downstream of the combustion zone
options.C: The fan is located upstream of the combustion zone

questions.explanation: An induced-draft burner has a fan downstream of the combustion zone, pulling flue gases through the system. In contrast, a forced-draft burner has the fan upstream, pushing air into the combustion zone.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: What component helps keep the flame retained at the burner port of a monoport burner?
questions.explanation: A flame spreader helps keep the flame retained at the burner port of a monoport burner and spreads the flame. It also helps reduce the susceptibility to flashback.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: How many pulses per second does a pulse-combustion burner typically produce?
questions.explanation: A pulse-combustion burner operates at 60 to 70 pulses per second, with each pulse releasing 1/4 to 1/2 Btu/h. The pulses are self-sustaining after initial spark ignition.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 2: Gas burners

questions.question_text: What is the most common type of flame sensor used on modern gas-fired appliances?
questions.explanation: Flame rod sensors are the most common type of flame sensors on modern gas-fired appliances. They rely on a flame's ability to conduct current when voltage is applied across electrodes within the flame through flame ionization.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What material is a typical hot-surface igniter (HSI) made from?
questions.explanation: The hot-surface igniter (HSI) works like a light bulb filament and is typically made from a material like silicon carbide or nitride. When 120V AC passes through it, it glows white hot to ignite the gas.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What is a thermopile (powerpile) used for in gas appliances?

options.B: To power both the combustion safety and control circuits
options.C: To regulate the gas flow rate

questions.explanation: A thermopile consists of multiple thermocouples joined together to generate more voltage than a single thermocouple. The higher voltage allows it to power both the combustion safety and control circuits of an appliance with automatic controls.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What is the term used to describe the time it takes for a flame detector to respond to flame loss?
questions.explanation: Flame detectors respond to flame establishment and loss, with the response time referred to as the 'flame failure response time' or FFRT. The maximum allowable FFRT is determined by certification standards and the type of flame detection used.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What is a 'unirod' in flame sensing systems?

options.B: A combined spark igniter and flame sensor rod

questions.explanation: In some cases, the flame rod serves as the spark-igniter rod until a flame is established and then acts as a flame sensor. This system is often called a 'unirod' because one component performs both functions.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What causes a bimetal strip to curve with temperature changes?

options.B: The two metals having different temperature coefficients of expansion

questions.explanation: A bimetal strip is formed by welding two dissimilar metals together. Due to the different temperature coefficients of expansion of the metals, the strip bends or curves as the temperature changes.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What distinguishes an intermittent pilot from an interrupted pilot?

options.A: Intermittent pilots remain on during the entire firing cycle
options.B: Intermittent pilots are turned on to light the main flame and extinguished after flame is proved
options.C: Intermittent pilots remain on all the time
options.D: Intermittent pilots use hot-surface ignition only

questions.explanation: An intermittent pilot is turned on to light the main flame and extinguished after the flame has been proved. An interrupted pilot remains on only during the firing cycle, while a constant pilot remains on all the time.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What causes a noisy, lifting, blowing flame on a non-aerated pilot?
questions.explanation: High gas pressure causes a noisy, lifting, blowing flame on a non-aerated pilot. Proper pilot adjustment requires checking gas pressure and ensuring it is within manufacturer specifications.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What is the most common problem associated with aerated pilots?

options.B: Clogging due to dust or lint

questions.explanation: The most common problem with aerated pilots is clogging due to dust or lint. The air intake for an aerated pilot can draw in debris that blocks the small passages.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 3: Ignition and flame sensing

questions.question_text: What activates a flame rollout switch?

options.B: A rise in temperature near the burner area

questions.explanation: A flame rollout switch is a high-temperature limit switch wired to the burner ignition control. If it senses a rise in temperature from flame rollout (flame escaping the combustion chamber), it opens and de-energizes the gas valve.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What type of boilers require a low-water cut-off switch?

options.B: Steam boilers and water boilers over 400,000 Btu/h

questions.explanation: A low-water cut-off switch is required on all steam boilers and water boilers with a capacity over 400,000 Btu/h, and when any part of the heating system is located under the boiler.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What is the function of a pressure differential airflow switch in a high-efficiency furnace?

options.A: To regulate gas pressure to the burner
options.B: To sense venting action by measuring pressure across its mechanism

questions.explanation: A pressure differential switch senses airflow by the pressure differential across its sensing mechanism. In high-efficiency furnaces, it is used to sense the venting action and prove that the inducer motor is operating properly.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What typically causes flame rollout in a gas furnace?

options.B: Failure to vent flue products from the combustion chamber or heat exchanger failure

questions.explanation: Flame rollout usually results from the failure to vent flue products from the combustion chambers or a heat exchanger failure. If the burner flame becomes trapped or disturbed inside a heat exchanger, it may flash back or roll outside the combustion chamber area.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What is commonly (but incorrectly) called a 'spill switch'?
questions.explanation: Furnaces with a draft hood may be equipped with a blocked-vent shut-off system that automatically turns off the main burner when the vent is completely blocked. These are commonly but incorrectly known as 'spill switches.'
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of an operating aquastat on a boiler?

options.A: To maintain water pressure in a boiler system
options.C: To energize or de-energize the main gas valve in response to water temperature

questions.explanation: The purpose of an operating aquastat is to energize or de-energize the main gas valve in response to the water temperature. It maintains the boiler water temperature within the desired operating range.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: How does the setting of a high-limit aquastat compare to an operating aquastat?

options.C: The same as the operating aquastat

questions.explanation: The temperature setting of a high-limit aquastat is higher than the setting of the operating aquastat. The high-limit provides safety protection if the operating control fails to shut off the burner.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: Where must the discharge from a temperature and pressure relief valve on a water heater be directed?

options.B: To an air gap as per local building codes
options.C: To the exterior of the building
options.D: Back to the cold water supply

questions.explanation: The discharge of relief valves must be directed to an air gap as per local building codes. The discharge piping must not have any restrictions or reductions in diameter, and the piping material must be suitable for discharge temperatures.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What causes the contacts of a steam boiler operating pressuretrol to open?

options.A: An increase in the water level

questions.explanation: The contacts of a steam boiler operating pressuretrol open in response to a rise in steam pressure. This de-energizes the gas valve to stop the burner when the desired pressure is reached.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 4: Control devices and safety systems

questions.question_text: What is a key advantage of tankless water heaters over storage-type water heaters?

options.B: Potentially twice the lifespan due to reduced rust and corrosion risk
options.C: Better water pressure at high flow rates

questions.explanation: Tankless water heaters have a potentially twice as long lifespan as traditional storage systems because, with proper maintenance, the risk of rust and corrosion can drop significantly since they have no storage tank.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: What does FVIR stand for in water heater design?
questions.explanation: FVIR stands for Flammable Vapour Ignition Resistance. This technology was developed for gas-fired water heaters to resist the ignition of flammable vapours outside of or near the heater.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: Which CSA B149.1-25 clause contains general installation requirements for decorative gas appliances?
questions.explanation: Clause 7.25 of CSA B149.1 contains general installation requirements for decorative gas appliances, such as gas logs and vented gas fireplaces including fireplace inserts, freestanding stoves, and zero-clearance units.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: What controls the drying period of a gas-fired clothes dryer?
questions.explanation: The drying period of a gas-fired clothes dryer is controlled by its moisture sensor. This allows the dryer to automatically stop when clothes reach the desired dryness level.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: Where is the blower located on a downflow furnace?

options.C: At the same level as the heat exchanger

questions.explanation: On a downflow furnace, the blower is located above the heat exchanger. The blower draws return air from above and pushes it down through the heat exchanger and out the bottom of the furnace.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: What type of vent is typically used with recessed wall furnaces?
questions.explanation: Type BW vents are approved for recessed wall furnaces. The oval shape of Type BW vents allows them to be installed inside a 2 x 4 stud wall where round vents would not fit.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: What normally controls the automatic gas valve on a forced warm-air furnace?

options.C: A thermostat mounted in the space being heated

questions.explanation: The automatic gas valve on a forced warm-air furnace is normally controlled by a thermostat mounted in the space being heated. The thermostat calls for heat when room temperature drops below the setpoint.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: What three types of gas-fired units can be used to heat a single room or small area?

options.A: Room space heaters, wall furnaces, baseboard heaters
options.B: Room space heaters, steam boilers, baseboard heaters
options.C: Baseboard heaters, room space heaters, infrared heaters

questions.explanation: Room space heaters, wall furnaces, and baseboard heaters are three types of gas-fired units that can be used to heat a single room or other small areas. Clause 7.17 and 7.24 contain installation requirements for these appliances.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 5: Gas appliances

questions.question_text: Who is authorized to perform fuel conversions on appliances with inputs of 400,000 Btu/h or less?

options.B: Only authorized individuals as per local regulations

questions.explanation: Only authorized individuals may perform fuel conversions on appliances with inputs of 400,000 Btu/h or less. The required qualifications vary by jurisdiction, so technicians must check local regulations.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.5.4, what must be marked on the appliance after a fuel conversion?

options.B: The gas to which it is converted on the appliance rating plate

questions.explanation: Per CSA B149.1-25 Clause 4.5.4, if an appliance is converted from one gas to another, the gas to which it is converted shall be marked on the appliance rating plate by the fitter making the conversion.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: Why is the orifice for propane smaller than the orifice for natural gas at the same heat output?

options.B: Propane has higher heat capacity, requiring smaller volume
options.C: Propane is delivered at lower pressure

questions.explanation: Although propane has a higher specific gravity than natural gas (limiting flow through an orifice), its heat capacity is higher, meaning a smaller volume of propane is required for the same heat production. Consequently, for the same heat output, a propane orifice is smaller.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: What device is used to check manifold gas pressure after a fuel conversion?
questions.explanation: A manometer is used to check the manifold gas pressure of a newly converted appliance. Pressure-measuring equipment is essential to confirm that the correct manifold pressure has been achieved after adjusting the regulator.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: What should be done with old gas piping after it has been replaced due to a fuel conversion?

options.A: Cleaned and restocked for use with the same fuel
options.B: Cleaned and restocked for use with any fuel
options.C: Removed or discarded in a safe manner

questions.explanation: Old gas piping should be removed or discarded in a safe manner after it has been replaced due to a fuel conversion. It should not be reused, regardless of cleaning.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: When converting from propane to natural gas and the propane tank will no longer be used, what must the installer do?

options.A: Nothing, the tank is the customer's responsibility
options.B: Shut off all valves, disconnect the pipe or tubing, and plug the openings

questions.explanation: When a propane tank will no longer be used, the installer must shut off all valves, disconnect the pipe or tubing, and plug the openings. Proper isolation prevents gas leakage and ensures safety.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: What must be done if the appliance manufacturer does not make a certified conversion kit and no similar model exists for the intended fuel?

options.B: Any qualified technician can perform the conversion
options.C: The conversion must be tested and labelled by the inspection authority or authorized agency
options.D: The homeowner can authorize the conversion

questions.explanation: If the appliance is certified only for one fuel and no conversion kit is available, the conversion must be tested and labelled (field-approved) by the inspection authority or an agency authorized by the inspection authority.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 6: Requirements for converting an appliance

questions.question_text: What is the most common cause of CO poisoning from gas equipment?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of CO poisoning from gas equipment can be found in venting system problems. This is why the venting system is the first system to check before reactivating an appliance.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: What does scorching on an appliance combustion chamber or surrounding area indicate?
questions.explanation: Scorching on the appliance combustion chamber or surrounding area indicates overheating. This condition requires checking if the appliance is overfiring or if there are restrictions in flue and vent passages.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: What does sooting on an appliance combustion chamber indicate?
questions.explanation: Sooting indicates incomplete combustion. The technician should check the appliance input rate and burner operation to ensure an adequate air supply, and check for restrictions in the flue or vent passages.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: How long must gas pressure be maintained and observed on a manometer during a pressure test of the gas supply system?
questions.explanation: The gas pressure indicated on the manometer or pressure test gauge must be maintained for a minimum of 10 minutes. Any decrease indicates a leak that must be located and repaired.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: What procedure must be performed on control valves and appliance piping before appliance reactivation?

options.B: A soap test under normal operating pressure
options.C: A lit taper test at all connections

questions.explanation: Upon completing the system gas pressure test, use an approved leak check soap solution to perform a leak test of all control valves and appliance piping (not previously tested) under normal operating pressure to confirm they are gastight.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: Why should the main valve to a natural gas regulator/meter set be turned on slowly during reactivation?

options.B: To allow the regulator time to react and prevent overpressure damage

questions.explanation: When reactivating a natural gas system, slowly turn on the main valve to a regulator/meter set. If turned on too quickly, the regulator will not have time to react, which could cause overpressure damage to the meter diaphragm, regulator, and other downstream gas controls.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: What does black powder coating on the interior of a draft diverter indicate?

options.A: The vent needs to be replaced
options.B: The burner needs adjusting or cleaning
options.C: The appliance needs to be replaced

questions.explanation: Black powder coating (carbon deposits) on the interior of a draft diverter indicates incomplete combustion and the need to make burner adjustments or clean the burner. This is a sign that combustion is not occurring properly.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of 'clocking the meter' when checking appliance input?

options.A: To ensure the meter is measuring properly
options.B: To verify the appliance input by measuring flow rate through the meter
options.C: To test for leaks in the system

questions.explanation: Clocking the meter refers to checking the input by measuring the flow rate through the meter by monitoring the test dial. This verifies that the appliance is firing at the correct input rate specified by the manufacturer.
unit_references: Unit 9 - Chapter 7: Reactivation of appliances

questions.question_text: Who may refuse to grant the authorization or revoke, suspend, or refuse to renew an authorization, if the authorization holder is in contravention of this Act?
questions.verification_source: Technical Standards and Safety Act, 2000 (TSSA), O. Reg. 212/01 - Gaseous Fuels
questions.notes: Under the TSSA Act, the Director has authority to refuse, revoke, suspend, or refuse to renew authorizations for contraventions of the Act.

questions.question_text: Who may only use force to enter and inspect a place where there is an immediate threat to public safety and only such force that is reasonably necessary in the circumstances?
questions.notes: TSSA Inspectors have powers of entry and inspection, including use of force in cases of immediate threat to public safety.

questions.question_text: Who shall order such investigation as he or she considers necessary on being notified of an accident or incident?
questions.notes: The Director is responsible for ordering investigations upon notification of accidents or incidents.

questions.question_text: Every ___________ shall take all reasonable precautions to ensure that they and their agents and employees comply with this Act, the regulations or a Ministers order
questions.notes: Employers have a statutory duty to ensure compliance with the Act by themselves, their agents and employees.

questions.question_text: Who is the 'authority having jurisdiction' referenced in the Code for Ontario
questions.verification_source: CSA B149.1-25, Technical Standards and Safety Act, O. Reg. 212/01
questions.clause_reference: CSA B149.1-25 Clause 3.13; O. Reg. 212/01 Section 2
questions.notes: TSSA is designated as the authority having jurisdiction for gas code enforcement in Ontario.

questions.question_text: An automatically controlled forced air furnace shall be equipped with a high temperature limit control, the maximum setting of the control shall be?
questions.notes: Per Clause 7.8.6: 'Automatically controlled gravity or forced-air furnace shall be equipped with high-temperature limit control with maximum setting of 350 degrees F for gravity furnace and 250 degrees F for forced-air furnace.'

questions.question_text: What is the maximum gas pressure allowed in a building under construction (construction heater application)?
questions.verification_source: O. Reg. 212/01 - Gaseous Fuels, CSA B149.1-25
questions.clause_reference: O. Reg. 212/01 Section 8; CSA B149.1-25 Clause 7.18
questions.notes: Standard delivery pressure for natural gas in building construction applications is typically limited to 2 PSIG for construction heater use. Higher pressures require additional safety provisions.

questions.question_text: A Notice of Proposal is not required to be provided by TSSA when?
questions.answer_text: When suspending a certification due to failure to pay certification fees
questions.notes: Administrative suspensions for non-payment of fees do not require a Notice of Proposal as they are not disciplinary actions.

questions.question_text: Which certification agency listed is not certified for appliance approvals in Ontario?
questions.notes: CSA, ULC, and UL International are recognized certification agencies for gas appliances. Ministry of Transportation is not an appliance certification body.

questions.question_text: Welded gas piping must comply with?
questions.verification_source: Technical Standards and Safety Act, 2000, O. Reg. 212/01
questions.notes: All gas piping installations including welded piping in Ontario must comply with the TSSA Act and its regulations.

questions.question_text: A Technician not agreeing with a Directors ruling may?
questions.answer_text: Appeal to the Ontario Divisional Court
questions.notes: Appeals from Director's decisions can be made to the Divisional Court under the TSSA appeal provisions.

questions.question_text: A person might be refused authorization where?
questions.notes: Lack of qualifications is a valid ground for refusing authorization under the TSSA Act.

questions.question_text: A Safety Order can be given?
questions.notes: Safety orders can be issued orally or in writing, with oral orders to be confirmed in writing as soon as practicable.

questions.question_text: No person shall remove a seal affixed by an Inspector:
questions.answer_text: Without consent from the Director of Fuel Safety TSSA
questions.notes: Only the Director can authorize removal of a seal affixed by an Inspector.

questions.question_text: The maximum fine for contravention of the Acts and Regulations for an individual is?
questions.notes: Maximum fine for individuals is $50,000 per TSSA Act Section 34(1).

questions.question_text: A Hydrocarbon is defined as?
questions.answer_text: Chemical compound of Hydrogen and Carbon
questions.verification_source: General chemistry definition, gas industry standard
questions.notes: A hydrocarbon is a chemical compound consisting of hydrogen and carbon atoms. Natural gas (methane CH4) and propane (C3H8) are hydrocarbons.

questions.question_text: Who has the responsibility under the Act of Inspecting and Accepting an Installation before supplying gas for the first time?
questions.notes: The gas distributor must inspect and accept an installation before first gas supply. This is a statutory duty under O. Reg. 212/01.

questions.question_text: No person shall operate a container refill center unless?
questions.verification_source: O. Reg. 212/01 - Gaseous Fuels, O. Reg. 211/01 - Propane Storage and Handling
questions.notes: Container refill centers require licensing under Ontario gas regulations.

questions.question_text: An 'indirect fired appliance' is defined as?
questions.answer_text: An appliance in which the flue gases are not mixed with the medium being heated
questions.notes: Per Clause 3.114: 'an appliance in which the combustion products or flue gases are not mixed within the appliance with the medium that is being heated.' Option B describes direct-fired, C describes direct-vent.

questions.question_text: A 'service regulator' is defined as?
questions.answer_text: Pressure regulator installed on a service line to control the pressure of the gas delivered to the customer
questions.notes: Per Clause 3.151: 'a pressure regulator installed on a service line to control the pressure of the gas delivered to the customer.' Option A describes appliance regulator (3.147), D describes overpressure relief device (3.134).

questions.question_text: A proved pilot is?
questions.answer_text: A pilot flame supervised by a primary safety control that senses the presence of a pilot prior to gas being admitted to the main burner
questions.notes: Per Clause 3.141: 'a pilot flame supervised by a primary safety control that senses the presence of the pilot prior to gas being admitted to the main burner.' Option B is continuous pilot (3.137), C is interrupted pilot (3.140), D is intermittent pilot (3.139).

questions.question_text: A stop fill valve is?
questions.answer_text: A device in a container that is intended to automatically shut off the flow of liquid into the container when a predetermined fixed level is achieved
questions.notes: Per Clause 3.189: 'a device in a container that is intended to automatically shut off the flow of liquid into the container when a predetermined fixed level is achieved.' Option A describes safety shut-off valve (3.188).

questions.question_text: Induced draft is?
questions.answer_text: A mechanical draft produced by a device downstream from the combustion zone of an appliance
questions.notes: Per Clause 3.62: 'a mechanical draft produced by a device downstream from the combustion zone of an appliance.' Option A is forced draft (3.61), C is natural draft (3.63), D is mechanical draft (3.60).

questions.question_text: When an appliance is installed on a roof, the clearance between the appliance and the edge of the roof or other hazard shall be at least?
questions.notes: Clause 4.14.6 specifies roof installation clearance requirements. The 6 ft (1.8 m) clearance from edge of roof or hazard is standard for rooftop appliance installations.

questions.question_text: For natural gas, threaded piping less than NPS 1/2 used in a piping system shall be?
questions.notes: Per Clause 6.3.8.1: 'For natural gas and hydrogen-natural gas blends, threaded pipe and fittings less than NPS 1/2 used in a piping system shall be Schedule 80.'

questions.question_text: A gas connector shall?
questions.answer_text: Not pass through a floor, wall, ceiling or partition
questions.notes: Per Clause 6.21.2: 'A gas connector shall be protected from damage, not pass through a wall, floor, ceiling, or partition, be connected to rigid piping or tubing located in the same area as the appliance.'

questions.question_text: A coil type boiler or water tube boiler having an input in excess of 400,000 Btu/hr requiring forced circulation to prevent overheating of the coils or tubes shall be equipped with a _______?
questions.notes: Boilers requiring forced circulation must be equipped with a flow sensing device to ensure water flow is maintained and prevent overheating. This is standard practice for high-input boilers with coil or tube designs.

questions.question_text: A moisture exhaust duct shall not terminate within _______feet in any direction of any pressure regulator vent termination or fresh air intake
questions.notes: Per Clause 7.5.2: 'Moisture-exhaust duct shall not terminate within 3 ft in any direction of any pressure regulator vent termination or outdoor air intake.'

questions.question_text: A hotplate shall be connected with ____________ and secured to prevent movement
questions.notes: Per Clause 7.29.1: 'Hotplate shall be connected with rigid piping and secured to prevent movement.'

questions.question_text: A type L vent may be used in lieu of a ____________ vent
questions.notes: Per Clause 8.10.10: 'A Type L vent may be used in lieu of a Type B vent.'

questions.question_text: A vent shall not terminate?
questions.answer_text: Within 6 feet of a mechanical air supply inlet to any building
questions.notes: Per Clause 8.14.8(c): 'A vent shall not terminate... within 6 ft (1.8 m) of a mechanical air-supply inlet to any building.' Note: The clause states 'less than 7 ft (2.1 m) above a paved sidewalk or driveway' making option A/C incorrect, and option D (6 ft from mechanical air supply) is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: A power venter certified for use as an add on to a water heater may be used on a water heater that has an input of _________ Btu/hr or less
questions.notes: Per Clause 8.29.2: 'A power venter certified for use as an add-on to a water heater may be used on a water heater that has an input of 50 000 Btu/h (15 kW) or less.'
